column4: ok, let's put it this way: does ubuntu 7.04 have support for msi us54se wireless usb stick?
sorry, epressed enter too soon
zydas driver is needed i think
THe 54 in the middle of that what I assume is Micro Star International model might imply the broadcom chipset
and is it supported?
Yes
the live cd didn't detect it
Do you have access to a hardwire lan connection
How are you on here?
What version of Ubuntu are you using?
http://www.murrayc.com/blog/permalink/2007/02/17/linux-compatible-wireless-usb-adaptor-results/
That should work out of the box..
It will not work out of the box on Dapper
The Networking control panel does not show a list of access points, so you must type in the access point name manually.  per that article
that's fine for me, i used ubuntu/kubuntu 5.10 and it didn't work
You should be good to go...
Reading is fine  You will need to enable ntfs-e6 to write
how do i do that?
Easy to do, when you have feisty installed we can go through the one click process
do i have to type the acces point name for any wireless stick/card or just for us54se?
I didnt got the broadcom.. so it may just be something in that one
ok
does ubuntu run on macintosh computers? (intel-based)
Are you downloading now or ?
There is a ppc version but I know nothing about it or even if it is still a project
if you are talking about ubuntu 7.04, nu, i am installing it now, allmost done
cool... let me know when you are done
ok
it's great, though i have to get used to using gaim instead of y! messenger
It detected the usb without any problems..
Good...
That page talked about feisty beat so that was fixed
Glad to have you with us, if you have any questions, just ask.  Be patient as this place gets busy and someone that knows the answer will help
a little bit more help pls, how can i download extra applications for ubuntu?
yes
Ask away
sudo gparted /dev/sda works but i cannot edit the partitions
dont you have gui desktop etc.. I would suggest gparted livecd for work at that level..
how can i make the installation process skip the "starting partition editor" part and go directly to complete formatting?
i have more than 700 files in my /dev folder, and the installer gets stuck
starting parted should give you the option for formatting..
so, just parted?
Perhaps you should provide more detail on what you are trying to do .. are you trying to edit a mounted partition. are you running livecd etc?
oh, so the partition should be unmounted, right
i'm trying to install ubuntu, but the installer gets stuck at loading the partition editor
livecd sometimes takes quite awhile to figure out your partitions...   You can run partition editor from the livecd desktop menus and avboid the installer too
partition editor gets stuck too
download gparted livecd  would be my suggestion

it doesn't freeze or something, but i think there are too many devices; i can't really boot from a cd unless wubi is for all bootable CDs; even if i format and partition my hdd with gparted, i still need to get past the "starting partition manager" screen in the installer, which doesn't work that well -- i would be glad if i could just skip that screen and pass /dev/sda directly to the installer
Sorry.. you never mentioned wubi...  I personally hate that program and would never recommend or support it
i don't know what that is, but it helped me boot from the live cd, since my bios is somehow broken
Starting from the beginning, what cd do you have
7.10 live & install cd, up and running
Sorry.. cant help you
How did you boot it?
installed wubi on windows and used that boot-time menu, or however you like to call it
Exactly my point...  I hate wasting my time on things like that
sorry?
np.. I would be happy to help you actuall install it.. just no wubi or vm anything
sorry? as in "i didn't understaind what you have said", but what is wubi anyway?
read up where you got it.. it is not a real installation
it vreates a simulated partition /installation insde a folder
only if it is booted and not simulated under windows
i'm not under windows
Power up with the cd in the drive  and tell me the first menu you see

before installing wubi on windows: nothing, it boots from the hard disk, i can't change that since my bios is somehow broken; after installing wubi on windows and *rebooting*, i get a simple bootloader-like menu where i can choose  "windows xp pro" or "ubuntu-linux"
ok, what's my problem?
how many "files" (or whatever the names represent) has an average linux user in /dev?
There are many ways to actually install ubuntu...
At start or install press F6 and remove Quiet and Splash from the command line. If it still fails.. Repeat and after removing quiet and splash add noapic acpi=off before the "--"
the problem is with the bios, it doesn't boot from CD
i have just bought a new hdd and installed it
you need some sort of bootable media or put the hd in a different box
it's a hardy cd, it's bootable
Does it work in another machine?
it does, it's an ordered CD
the installer gives you those options
the HARDY installer..
will setting "/dev/sda6" to have the mount point in "/home" be enogh?
YEs, it should let you set the /home and not require you to format it
Would you like to share your thoughts? Will my settings files get overwritten?
I cant say specifically but it seemed to leave eveything in good order.. do a system backup with tar if you have concerns
many thanks :) some quick snippet for tar-ing ".*" files and folders?
here is one of mine   tar cvpzf backupdell.tgz --exclude=/backupdell.tgz --exclude=/proc --exclude=/lost+found  --exclude=/mnt --exclude=/sys --exclude=/media --exclude=/root/.Trash -- /
does tar have some sort of regexpr or wildcart (I belive this is how it's called) pattern matching for filenames?
or could I use „ls“ together with tar?
man tar to find other options  but ls I dont think is one of them
that's not what I meant
i was thinking of something like "ls -al | grep *.jpg", but the other way round
Please stop  C++ has a channel
you need build essentials and possibly kernel headers
what's the kernel headers package
sudo apt-get install build-essential linux-headers-`uname -r`
﻿`uname -r`?
feel free to replace it with the results of uname -r from terminal session
just saves you the trouble
what package
